title: Create Visuals & Diagrams guide page
description:
Create a new documentation page explaining how visual diagrams provide both high-level structural clarity and low-level execution logicâ€”and why they're easy to generate with LLMs.

## Page Content

### 1. The C4 Model: Architectural Hierarchy
Explain the C4 model as a 'map' for software architecture that allows zooming in/out depending on audience (CEO vs Lead Developer):

- **Level 1: System Context** - Bird's-eye view showing the system as a single box with interactions to users and external systems (Stripe, AWS, etc.)
- **Level 2: Containers** - Zooms into the system to show high-level technical building blocks (Web App, Mobile App, Database, File Store)
- **Level 3: Components** - Zooms into a single container to show internal logical components (Payment Controller, Email Service)
- **Level 4: Code** - Most granular view (UML class diagrams, ER diagrams). Often omitted in modern agile or auto-generated.

### 2. Task Graphs: Execution Flow
Explain Task Graphs (Directed Acyclic Graphs / DAGs) for representing operations with dependencies:

- **Parallelism** - Running independent tasks simultaneously
- **Conditionals** - 'If Task A fails, go to Task C; if succeeds, go to Task B'
- **Cycles/Loops** - Re-running tasks until conditions are met (common in AI agents that self-correct)

Relate to agentic frameworks like LangGraph and CrewAI.

### 3. Why LLMs Excel at Diagrams
Explain how LLMs can easily generate Mermaid/PlantUML diagrams from natural language descriptions.
